Award.AwardTitle: A Comparative Study of Ethnic Entrepreneurship in U.S. Immigration Gateways

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project investigates the spatial dimensions of entrepreneurial success of immigrants and ethnic minorities in several US cities. Entrepreneurship plays an important role in stimulating economic development and growth, and research to-date indicates that entrepreneurship could provide ethnic minorities with a springboard for economic progress as well as further social and political advancement in the cities they inhabit. The proliferation of small businesses can also help neighborhood revitalization in some low income, ethnic communities. However, the rate of business start-up and survival differs by race/ethnicity, gender, foreign-born status, and place. Through a comparative framework this project seeks to analyze the spatial patterns of ethnic minority-owned-enterprises (EMEs) at multiple scales and examines how spatial embeddedness influences their formation and performance. Using a geographic perspective that links place, ethnicity, gender, and entrepreneurship, two research questions will be addressed in this project: (1) How are EMEs socially and spatially embedded in different places? (2) What is the role of place in the performance and development of EMEs? Facilitated by the use of a micro-level census dataset, the spatial pattern and performances of EMEs will be analyzed using advanced spatial analytical techniques and multilevel regression across all metropolitan areas in the U.S. Detailed analyses at the local scale will be conducted in a selection of different immigration gateways. "Vertical" (one ethnic group across multiple places) and "horizontal" (multiple groups within one place) comparisons will be made to permit a high degree of flexibility when comparing and representing different types of US metropolitan areas by simultaneously considering socioeconomic forces at both local and macro levels.

This project will promote an understanding of the opportunities and challenges facing ethnic minorities and women in their economic integration through entrepreneurship. This is important, especially given the current national push for economic recovery, to the ethnic minority labor force, economic development practitioners, the immigrant support community, and urban policy makers. The project will promote education of the public, students, and the next generation of entrepreneurs through developing entrepreneurship-centered curricula, directly mentoring and supporting students, launching an interdisciplinary research group on ethnic entrepreneurship and immigration, and reaching out to ethnic minority entrepreneurs, local communities, and government agencies.

POR.DRECONTENT:
A Comparative Study of Ethnic Entrepreneurship in the U. S. Immigration Gateways

 

Through both quantitative analyses of multiple national datasets and qualitative case studies, this project has analyzed the spatial patterns of ethnic minority owned enterprises at multiple scales and examined how spatial embeddedness influences the formation and performances of minority firms.

 

Based on a multidisciplinary literature, a holistic framework is developed to assess the spatial dimensions of ethnic entrepreneurship at varying scales (from individual entrepreneur and firm, to residential and business community; and to regional labor markets) to explain how place, ethnicity, gender and entrepreneurship interact. As the central social actors, ethnic entrepreneurs weave through multiscaled geographic contexts in the process of creatively mobilizing and capitalizing entrepreneurial resources in the labor markets. The multiscaled geographic contexts provide a milieu of social, economic, political, cultural, and regulatory factors and forces. The interaction between the social actors and their social-spatial contexts further influences entrepreneurs’ values of entrepreneurship, perception of entrepreneurial opportunities, practical management strategies, and ultimately their business performances. While a large number of interdisciplinary studies have provided valuable insights into understanding entrepreneurship, these studies have not yet developed a “coherent and spatially informed” analytical framework. Even less is known when it concerns ethnicity and gender. Therefore, this project brings geography to the forefront of ethnic entrepreneurship studies. Within geography, this study will also bridge the serious gaps of knowledge in entrepreneurship among sub-disciplines of geography by linking place, ethnicity, gender, and entrepreneurship together.

 

Through analyses of ethnic entrepreneurship from a multi-scaled and comparative approach, this project provides empirical knowledge about ethnic entrepreneurship in both the ethnic enclave economy and the mainstream economy by working in traditional immigration gateways and new destinations. For example, one study finds that a negative relationship between spatial concentration of African American and their business ownership holds true in Miami, but not in Atlanta. In Detroit, a higher percentage of U.S.-born African-Americans in the local labor market is actually associated with a higher probability of their business ownership. The relationship between the percentage of African American and jobs earnings also differ across the metropolitan areas. Results suggest the relationship between racial/ethnic concentration and entrepreneurship for African-Americans is highly contingent on the economic conditions and demographic composition in the local labor markets.  Overall, the comparative approach will not only advance our empirical knowledge about ethnic entrepreneurship but also shed light on the transformation of traditional theories surrounding ethnic socioeconomic integration, gender, immigration, and equity issues.

 

This project has paid particular attention to the interaction between race, ethnicity, gender, and entrepreneurship. At the national level, male- and female- owned businesses are found to have distinctive industrial concentration patterns, with ethnic minority women-owned businesses in particular highly concentrated in a limited number of industrial sectors. However, the localized qualitative studies have highlighted that women business owners tend to be more holistic in measuring their success and goals. In particular, women’s entrepreneurship can contribute to community life in ways that go beyond traditional economic metrics, bring economically viable and innovative ideas, transform power relations, and bring great potential for socioeconomic success within local communities. Overall, the findings are not simply challenging traditional views on entrepreneurship and practices of community development; they have also suggested to examine the diversity and fluidity of the entrepreneurial process, as well as to promote entrepreneurship that can empower disadvantaged groups as engines of community development.

 

This project has profound and timely public policy implications by promoting understanding of the opportunities and challenges facing ethnic minorities in their economic integration and labor market upward mobility through entrepreneurship. In light of the national push for economic recovery, this study helps to better understand the dynamics and spatial domains of business development, evaluate both benefits and limitations of ethnic social capital dependency and promote long-term healthy development of ethnic economies. Ultimately, it will enhance scientific knowledge and serve to articulate the ever-growing importance of ethnic minority-owned enterprises in changing social, political, and economic landscapes of the nation.

 

Results from this project have been widely published in peer-reviewed academic journals and media outlets, presented at regional, national, and local conferences, and integrated into both the undergraduate and graduate curricula. Through specially-designed courses, seminars, and workshops at different stages of this project, both undergraduate and graduate students have been trained, supported and mentored. Colleagues and professionals from multiple higher education institutions and organizations have joined this project as collaborators.  For example, the Business and Economic Development Center at the University of Washington Seattle, the Kauffman Foundation, the Washington Center for Equitable Growth, UNC Charlotte Urban Institute, and Latin American Economic Development Corporation are among those who have joined the efforts continued from the current project to promote minority entrepreneurship and sustainable growth in underserved communities.
